message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of leg cramping, runny nose, chills, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and yawning suggest the patient is experiencing opioid withdrawal. The elevated heart rate, hyperactive bowel sounds, and equal-sized pupils are also characteristic of opioid withdrawal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of leg cramping, runny nose, chills, diarrhea, abdominal pain, irritability, and yawning suggest opioid withdrawal, most likely heroin. Cool, damp skin with piloerection, hyperactive bowel sounds, and 3+ deep tendon reflexes are also indicative of opioid withdrawal. Gamma-hydroxybutyric acid withdrawal may present with hallucinations and seizures, but not with the symptoms described in the question. Barbiturate withdrawal may present with seizures and confusion, but not with the symptoms described in the question. Cocaine withdrawal may result in depression and fatigue, but not with the symptoms described in the question.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including leg cramping, runny nose, chills, diarrhea, and abdominal pain, point to opioid withdrawal, and the high pulse rate and hyperactive bowel sounds confirm this. The other options are not associated with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest opioid withdrawal, and among the options, only heroin is an opioid. Runny nose, chills, and yawning are common symptoms of opioid withdrawal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of leg cramping, runny nose, chills, diarrhea, and abdominal pain suggest opiate withdrawal, and the patient's pulse rate and cool, damp skin with piloerection are consistent with opiate withdrawal as well. Gamma-hydroxybutyric acid withdrawal can cause agitation, hallucinations, and tremors. Barbiturate withdrawal can cause seizures, hypertension, and tachycardia. Cocaine withdrawal can cause depression and fatigue.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest opioid withdrawal, and among the options, only heroin is an opioid. The cool, damp skin with piloerection, pupils’ dilation, hyperactive bowel sounds, and fast pulse are all classic opioid withdrawal symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described, including leg cramping, runny nose, chills, and diarrhea, are classic symptoms of heroin withdrawal. The hyperactive bowel sounds and 3+ deep tendon reflexes are also characteristic of opioid withdrawal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest opiate withdrawal, especially with the presence of leg cramping and yawning. Gamma-hydroxybutyric acid withdrawal would cause anxiety and insomnia, not chills and diarrhea. Barbiturate withdrawal would cause anxiety, tremors, and seizures, not cool, damp skin and hyperactive bowel sounds. Cocaine withdrawal would cause fatigue and depression, not chills and diarrhea.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest opiate withdrawal, and the sweating, chills, yawning, and hyperactive bowel sounds are common symptoms. None of the other substances listed exhibit these symptoms during withdrawal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest opioid withdrawal, and among the options, only heroin is an opioid. Symptoms of opioid withdrawal include leg cramping, runny nose, chills, diarrhea, abdominal pain, irritability, and yawning. The pupil size, skin appearance, and reflexes are also consistent with opioid withdrawal.
